div1.head: Letter from Albert G. Love to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 4, 1943
div1.opener:
IN REPLY REFER TO SPMC G
AGL:jm
WAR DEPARTMENT
SERVICES OF SUPPLY
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
4 August 1943
Brigadier General Jefferson R. Kean,
2804 N Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Many thanks for your very kind letter of August 2 with the
comments on our review of General Truby's book. I am especially
grateful for your corrections of the statements with regard to
✓ Dr. Ames and Sargeant Neate. It would have been most unfortunate
if the review had been published with the paragraph as originally
written. You will appreciate, however, that I had no idea at any
time of publishing any review of the book without your going over
the manuscript very carefully.

Although I have no defense for my error in writing the paragraph
as I did, I was probably misled to a certain extent by General Truby's
comments with regard to Sargeant Neate on pages 93 and 94. With re-
ference to Dr. Ames, he speaks of him so frequently that I gained the
wrong impression. Even now it appears to me that Dr. Ames was really
of greater service to the Board than Agramonte.

I am sending you the revised manuscript. You will notice that I
have made some minor changes in your revision of the paragraph in
question. I did this because it occurred to me that a statement of
what the men did and why they were not entitled to be included on the
Roll of Honor would be more effective to the reader than the decision
of a board no matter how well qualified the members of the board were.

Please look over the manuscript and if you approve it, return the
original to me and retain the carbon copy for your file. If you do not
approve it, return both and I will then send you a revised carbon.
div1.closer:
Cordially, Albert G Love ALBERT G. LOVE,
Colonel, Medical Corps.
FOR VICTORY
BUY
UNITED
STATES
WAR
BONDS
AND
STAMPS
Incl. 2 mss.
ALL COMMUNICATIONS SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO “THE SURGEON GENERAL, U. S. ARMY, WASHINGTON, D. C.”
